awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide participant support to the conference "Ideals, Varieties, and Applications" (https://iva2019.wordpress.amherst.edu/) to be held June 10-14 in Amherst, MA.  The organizers will bring together graduate students and researchers at all levels to survey the state of the art in computational and combinatorial algebraic geometry. The conference will aim to provide mentorship and support for graduate students and early-career researchers and will stress the idea that mathematicians from a diverse range of institutions can make significant and lasting contributions to mathematics and its connections to other disciplines.  Many of the conference topics are motivated by applications outside of mathematics; further breakthroughs will result in fruitful interplay between disciplines, and a more prominent role for computational algebraic geometry in science and engineering, building on the role it is already establishing in fields such as computer vision, modeling, and computational biology. 

Modern computational algebraic geometry began with the invention of Groebner bases in 1965, which form the backbone of many practical algorithms developed since then.  A special emphasis will be placed on illustrating how computation of Groebner bases drives both theory and applications. In particular, speakers will cover advances in algorithms, toric varieties, Cox rings, syzygies, tropical algebraic geometry, geometric modeling, and applications to computer-aided-design (CAD).  The organizers will emphasize  recent open problems ripe for work by early-career scholars with solid algebra training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Ideals, Varieties, and Applications conference was held from Monday, June 10 through Friday, June 14, 2019, at Amherst College in Amherst, MA. The conference brought together experts, early career mathematicians, and graduate students studying computational and combinatorial algebraic geometry. The theory of Grobner bases, introduced in 1965, has become a key pillar in studying ideals in multivariable polynomial rings, and their use underlies many of the topics of the conference, including toric varieties, tropical geometry, Cox rings, geometric modeling, syzygies, and much more, including applications to geometric computer aided design, combinatorics, and computational algorithms in algebraic geometry. The conference provided a stimulating setting for mathematicians doing research in these areas to share their expertise, generate new interactions, and provide early-career mathematicians an opportunity to present their results.
The conference had 90 registered participants, including 10 postdoctoral scholars and more than 30 graduate students. There were 21 talks given by experts on the topics of the conference, presenting cutting edge research while making the material accessible for early career scholars to engage actively in the informal discussions that followed the talks. There was also an early career panel discussion, a software Q+A session, and a poster session featuring 14 posters presented by graduate students and other early-career mathematicians on their work.
The conference participants had a high level of professional interaction during the conference. The mathematical conversations continued enthusiastically during the break times, with early-career mathematicians interacting freely with established researchers. At the poster session, these same established experts also eagerly engaged the graduate students and postdocs who were presenting their own research. Besides the speakers, NSF funding helped provide travel support for many of the graduate students and recent PhDs, making attendance possible for many more young researchers than would otherwise have been the case.
